title: John Batchelor- 50 Years Since Chinese Cultural Revolution

â€œâ€¦Women like to wear leggings and tight tops â€” Elle is the most popular brand among women, while men prefer Adidas and Nike â€” she said. When young people go to China, they travel armed with shopping lists from their friends for workout gear.

At a leisure complex next to the bowling alley in the middle of Pyongyang, they run on the treadmills, which show #Disney cartoons on the monitors, or do yoga.

The complex also has a fancy restaurant that advertises for wedding functions â€” glitzy Â­venues cost as much as $500 an hour â€” and a coffee shop, where most drinks are priced between $4 and $8, although an iced mocha costs $9.

â€œItâ€™s a cool spot. When youâ€™re in there it feels like you could be anywhere in the world,â€ said Andray Abrahamian, who is British and helps run an exchange program that provides financial training to #NorthKoreans. He recently played squash on one of the three courts at the center. â€œItâ€™s not cheap. Itâ€™s a few dollars for a class. Itâ€™s definitely for people who have disposable income.â€
